report_title: Athleisure Clothing Manufacturing in the US
executive_summary: The COVID-19 pandemic initially had a negative impact on athleisure sales in 2020 due to unfavorable economic conditions, but later led to higher demand as social distancing increased outdoor and at-home physical activities. Consumers also increasingly wore athleisure for day-to-day activities. After significant gains in 2021-2022, tightening economic conditions caused losses. Revenue grew at an estimated 1.0% CAGR to $993.0 million through 2024.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Demand for athleisure clothes rose in the last few years as the line between athleisure and casual clothing blurred, with more people wearing athletic clothes for everyday activities. The pandemic led to a spike in outdoor and leisure activities, boosting demand. However, weaker economic conditions and high inflation have also contributed to sluggish demand as athleisure wear is considered discretionary.

Domestic producers face significant competition from foreign manufacturers that can offer more affordable products due to lower operating costs overseas. The strong US dollar has enabled imported apparel to capture larger domestic market share. Rising inflation has also pushed cost-conscious consumers towards more affordable imported products, impacting domestic manufacturers.

Input price volatility, particularly for cotton which is a major input, directly impacts profitability for athleisure manufacturers. Cotton prices dropped during the pandemic due to falling demand but later jumped as manufacturing resumed, impacted by environmental conditions and changes in demand.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Improving economic conditions will enable revenue growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the economy stabilizes, consumers will spend more time on leisure and sports, boosting demand for athleisure apparel. Subsiding inflation and favorable economic conditions will support apparel demand.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A weakening dollar is likely to boost trade activity
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The expected dollar depreciation will make domestic products more affordable domestically and internationally, but lower overseas costs will still give foreign manufacturers a price advantage.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Manufacturers expected to benefit from moderating input prices
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Cotton prices are expected to stabilize over the next few years. If international conflicts are resolved, prices may weaken further as supply chain conditions improve and trade tariffs ease.

industry_definition: Manufacturers of athleisure clothing produce athletic apparel for men, women, boys and girls that can also be used for leisure activities. Apparel includes leggings, sweatpants, athletic shorts and swimwear, among other products. This industry only includes companies that operate their own production facilities in the United States.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - Per capita disposable income

key_trends: Significant competition from foreign manufacturers harms domestic sales due to a weaker dollar enabling them to capture larger domestic market share.
A recovering economy and growing interest in sports paved the way for revenue expansion after the pandemic's initial impact.
Improving economic conditions expected to continue driving growth, though foreign competition remains a threat. Expected dollar depreciation will make domestic apparel more affordable.
Regulations aim to protect manufacturers through piracy protection and customs laws preventing cheaper look-alike product sales.
Import penetration into the manufacturing sector continues expanding, with imported athleisure apparel widely popular among consumers.
Manufacturers with their own retail stores are more profitable by cutting out the middleman.
The female market generates the most revenue due to diverse clothing and high demand for women's and girls' athleisure apparel.
New manufacturers struggle to compete with larger established brands investing heavily in advertising and favoring consumer preferences.
Producers rely directly on consumer demand, with changes in preferences impacting revenue.
Multiple companies produce athleisure apparel to provide options for different brands, styles and designs attracting consumers.
Manufacturers face significant competition from foreign producers able to offer lower prices due to lower overseas operating costs.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Specialty stores refer to clothing retailers that operate as brick-and-mortar locations, including manufacturer-owned retail outlets. This segment accounts for 42% of the market.
No data provided on the general merchandise segment.

This segment includes wholesalers that buy from manufacturers and sell to retailers at a markup. Demand from wholesalers has been declining but they remain relevant for smaller retailers. This segment accounts for 19.2% of the market.
E-commerce solutions are expanding rapidly due to the pandemic and changing consumer preferences towards online shopping. This segment accounts for 18.2% of the market.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes leggings, jeans, sweatpants, workout sets, tennis skirts and other sports apparel for women and girls.
This segment includes swimsuits and other apparel used for swimming and leisure time for women and girls.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes shorts, polo and sports shirts, sweatpants, jogging suits, jeans and other products for athletic purposes for men and boys, including swimwear.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Changing fashion trends contribute to demand for swimwear as consumers aim to purchase swimsuits that are in style.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Rise in popularity of yoga and pilates
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The rise in popularity of yoga and pilates has boosted demand from women for athleisure clothing.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has the highest percentage of establishments at around 30% and population at around 25%.
The West region has around 20% of establishments and 15% of population.
The New England region has the lowest percentage of around 5% for both establishments and population.
The Rocky Mountains region also has around 5% of establishments and population.

basis_points.basis_description: New manufacturers will struggle to successfully compete with larger brands.
New athleisure apparel producers must ensure they manufacture products that favor consumer preferences and make it a point to invest heavily in advertising.
Producers rely directly on consumer demand. Apparel manufacturers have plenty of options for fabric producers, but changes in consumer preferences can cause revenue to take a hit.
Multiple companies are producing athleisure apparel. Consumers like to have options for different brands, styles, and designs.
Manufacturers face significant competition from foreign producers. Lower operating costs overseas make it possible for these producers to offer lower prices, boosting price competition.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Inputs include fabrics, yarns, buttons, zippers and other materials necessary for apparel production. Tariff costs lead to higher purchase costs.
Apparel manufacturers rely heavily on labor, making it difficult for domestic companies to compete with manufacturers in developing countries where labor costs are lower.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Both the rate of new innovation and the concentration are in line with the average across all industries.

volatility_points.volatility_title: CHANGING CONSUMER PREFERENCES AND SIGNIFICANT COMPETITION CHALLENGE ATHLEISURE MANUFACTURERS
volatility_points.volatility_description: Fashion trends change frequently. Athleisure manufacturers find themselves having to consistently produce new designs.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The pace of technology updates is slow.

FAQs.question: What markets do you currently export to? Do you have plans to export into new markets?
FAQs.answer: As trading conditions in the domestic market become more difficult, companies can enhance their prospects through developing export markets.

FAQs.question: How quickly are you able to accommodate for new trends? How are you able to ensure goods are high quality once altered?
FAQs.answer: Companies need to be up-to-date on trends and be able to offer high-quality products that reflect these.

FAQs.question: What kind of skills do you seek out in your workforce? Do you require training for new employees to meet certain skill standards?
FAQs.answer: Changes in downstream demand can alter workflows and production requirements. Operators that have a workforce that is able to adapt.

FAQs.question: How do you track participation in sports? How do you plan to capitalize on expected increases in sports participation?
FAQs.answer: As more people exercise, demand for athleisure clothes increases.

FAQs.question: Do you track the price of cotton? How do you mitigate the potential threat of increasing prices?
FAQs.answer: Cotton prices account for one of the largest input costs for industry operators.

FAQs.question: How will rising disposable income over the coming years impact your service offerings? Can you offer higher-end or premium products?
FAQs.answer: Athleisure wear is considered nonessential and purchases of such clothing will likely be reduced when income is restricted.
